questions.question: A ball is launched horizontally from the top of a 45 m tall cliff with an initial speed of 20 m/s. How long does it take to reach the ground? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
An object is launched at an angle of 30° above the horizontal with a speed of 40 m/s. What is the initial horizontal component of its velocity?
At the very highest point (apex) of a projectile's path, which of the following statements is true regarding its velocity?
options: Both components are equal and non-zero.
The vertical velocity is zero, but horizontal velocity is non-zero.
The horizontal velocity is zero, but vertical velocity is non-zero.
questions.explanation: At apex, vertical velocity becomes zero while horizontal velocity remains constant (neglecting air resistance).

questions.question: A stone is thrown horizontally at 15 m/s from a bridge. If it hits the water 2.5 s later, how far horizontally from the bridge does it land?
Which physical principle explains why a bullet dropped and a bullet fired horizontally from the same height hit the ground at the same time?
questions.explanation: Vertical and horizontal motions are independent. Both bullets have same initial vertical velocity (0) and same vertical acceleration.

questions.question: A projectile is launched with an initial vertical velocity of 30 m/s. How much time does it take to reach its maximum height? (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
Neglecting air resistance, what is the horizontal acceleration of a projectile while it is in the air?
options: It decreases as the object rises.
It depends on the initial launch speed.
questions.explanation: No horizontal force acts on the projectile, so horizontal acceleration = 0.

questions.question: What is the shape of the path (trajectory) followed by any projectile?
questions.explanation: Under constant gravity with no air resistance, projectile motion follows a parabolic path.

questions.question: A projectile is launched from ground level at some angle. If the total time of flight is 8 seconds, at what time does it reach its maximum height?
options: It depends on the mass of the projectile.
questions.explanation: Time to maximum height = half of total flight time for symmetrical trajectory: $8/2 = 4$ s.

questions.question: Calculate the maximum height reached by a projectile launched vertically with an initial speed of 20 m/s. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered the fundamentals of projectile motion.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review the independence of horizontal and vertical motions.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on separating projectile motion into components.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review. Study how initial velocity components determine time of flight and range.
